channel.title: Bloomberg Politics
channel.copyright: Copyright 2025 BLOOMBERG L.P. ALL RIGHTS RESERVED

item.title: Starmer Discusses Easing UK Welfare Cuts With Labour Rebels
item.description: Prime Minister Keir Starmer looks ready to water down another of the UK government’s key policies, offering concessions to stop Labour party colleagues derailing his reforms to Britain’s expensive welfare payments.
item.dc:creator: Alex Wickham, Julian Harris

media:content.media:description: Keir Starmer

item.title: Iran Caused $3 Billion of Damage With Missile Strikes on Israel
item.description: Israel has estimated the cost of damages incurred during its 12-day war with Iran at 10 billion shekels ($3 billion), with funds needed both to repair missile-hit buildings and pay compensation to local businesses.
item.dc:creator: Galit Altstein

media:content.media:description: Rescuers amid the debris of damaged buildings in Tel Aviv following an Iranian missile attack.

item.title: South African President Weighing Changes to Cabinet, News24 Says
item.description: South African President Cyril Ramaphosa is weighing changes to his cabinet, including removing the nation’s deputy trade minister who’s a member of the second-largest party in the ruling coalition.
item.dc:creator: Paul Vecchiatto

media:content.media:description: Cyril Ramaphosa

item.title: Kenyan Protest Death Toll Climbs to 16 After Police Crackdown
item.description: At least 16 people died after Kenyan police cracked down on anti-government protests across the country on Wednesday, human-rights groups said.
item.dc:creator: David Herbling

media:content.media:description: Protesters run from the police during a demonstration in Nairobi, on June 25.

item.title: New York’s Leftward Shift Jolts US Politics
item.description: Zohran Mamdani’s ascendancy has rocked the political establishment in the world’s financial capital
item.dc:creator: Gregory Korte

media:content.media:description: Zohran Mamdani, New York City mayoral candidate, rolls up his sleeves during a campaign event in New York, US, on Monday, June 23, 2025. New Yorkers will head to the polls Tuesday to choose a Democratic candidate for mayor as a sweltering heat wave engulfs the city, and with tightened security in place after the US unleashed airstrikes on Iran. Photographer: Adam Gray/Bloomberg

item.title: Spain’s Leader Calls Trump Tariffs ‘Doubly Unfair’ in Trade Spat
item.description: Prime Minister Pedro Sanchez defended his decision to break with his NATO allies over increases in military spending and called President Donald Trump’s threat to impose higher tariffs on Spain “doubly unfair.”
item.dc:creator: Daniel Basteiro, Ben Sills

media:content.media:description: Pedro Sanchez in Brussels on June 26. Photographer: Nicolas Tucat/AFP/Getty Images

item.title: Farage’s Reform Would Come Top in UK Election, YouGov Finds
item.description: Nigel Farage’s populist Reform UK would be the biggest party in parliament if the country held a general election today, according to a nationwide projection, underlining the political danger to Prime Minister Keir Starmer.
item.dc:creator: Alex Morales

media:content.media:description: Reform UK leader Nigel Farage

item.title: Starmer Acknowledges Asking ‘a Lot’ of UK Firms With Tax Hikes
item.description: Prime Minister Keir Starmer acknowledged the impact his government’s tax increases have had on UK firms as he faces strong calls from business to resist further hikes in the autumn budget.
item.dc:creator: Joe Mayes, Freya Jones

media:content.media:description: Keir Starmer, UK prime minister, at the British Chambers of Commerce (BCC) Global Annual Conference in London, UK, on Thursday, June 26, 2025. The UK is seeking to increase the recognition of British professional certifications abroad, a move aimed at boosting the nation’s service-sector exports by making it easier for highly skilled employees to work for clients overseas.

item.title: China to Relax Urea Export Ban, Easing Global Price Pressure
item.description: China is loosening its ban on urea exports, a move likely to ease international prices that have been buoyed by the recent tension in the Middle East.
item.dc:creator: Hallie Gu, Alfred Cang

media:content.media:description: Shipping containers at the Yantian International Container Terminals in Shenzhen, China. Photographer: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg

item.title: France to Curb Spending as Government Sees Slippage From Plans
item.description: France’s government said it will need to cut spending by an extra €5 billion ($5.9 billion) this year to meet its deficit reduction target after seeing some slippage from the initial budget plan.
item.dc:creator: William Horobin

media:content.media:description: Eric Lombard

item.title: Trump Pivots to Tax Cuts to Combat Voters’ Economic Anxiety
item.description: President Donald Trump is pivoting his attention to passing the cornerstone of his legislative agenda, pressuring Congress to quickly approve a massive tax bill that Republicans believe will seal their political fortunes in the midterm elections.
item.dc:creator: Nancy Cook, Kate Sullivan

media:content.media:description: US President Donald Trump

item.title: EU’s Ribera Won’t Trade Big Tech Rules to Placate Trump
item.description: The European Union’s crackdown on Apple Inc., Meta Platforms Inc., and Alphabet Inc.’s Google isn’t a bargaining chip in trade negotiations with US President Donald Trump, according to Teresa Ribera, the EU’s competition chief.
item.dc:creator: Samuel Stolton, Oliver Crook

media:content.media:description: Teresa Ribera Photographer: Ksenia Kuleshova/Bloomberg

item.title: German Lawmakers Back Merz’s €46 Billion Package of Tax Breaks
item.description: Chancellor Friedrich Merz’s €46 billion ($53 billion) package of tax breaks was approved by Germany’s lower house of parliament, paving the way for the measures to get final ratification in the upper house on July 11.
item.dc:creator: Kamil Kowalcze

media:content.media:description: Friedrich Merz on June 26. Photographer: Nicolas Tucat/Getty Images

item.title: Orban Touts Anti-Ukraine Survey to Boost His Flagging Campaign
item.description: Prime Minister Viktor Orban hailed the result of a government survey that showed Hungarians overwhelmingly against Ukraine’s European Union accession, and which critics derided as propaganda aimed at reversing his fading popularity.
item.dc:creator: Zoltan Simon

media:content.media:description: Viktor Orban on June 26.

item.title: Trump Says US and Iran Will Talk Next Week, Mideast War Over for Now
item.description: President Donald Trump said the US would hold a meeting with Iran next week but cast doubt on the need for a diplomatic agreement on the country’s nuclear program, citing the damage that American bombing had done to key sites.
item.dc:creator: Josh Wingrove, Jennifer A Dlouhy, Annmarie Hordern

media:content.media:description: US President Donald Trump during a news conference at the NATO summit in The Hague, on June 25.

item.title: UK’s Labour Needs to Contain Non-Dom Exodus, Lord Mayor Says
item.description: The UK government should act to stem an exodus of wealthy foreigners from the country following a major tax crackdown, said Alastair King, Lord Mayor of the City of London.
item.dc:creator: Leonard Kehnscherper

media:content.media:description: Alastair King

item.title: Is the Anti-Immigrant Reform UK Ready to Take Charge?
item.description: According to new polling, the far-right party led by Nigel Farage now stands at 34% support, nine points ahead of Labour and well ahead of the Conservatives.
item.dc:creator: Tala Ahmadi

media:content.media:description: TOPSHOT - People hold anti-racism placards as they take part in a "Stop the Far-right" demonstration on a National Day of Protest, outside of the headquarters of the Reform UK political party, in London on August 10, 2024. Brexit activist Nigel Farage, whose anti-immigration Reform UK party won 14 percent of the vote on the July 4 general election, has suggested the recent rioting stems from legitimate grievances about immigration, rather than simply far-right thuggery, and warned worse could be seen on the streets. (Photo by BENJAMIN CREMEL / AFP) (Photo by BENJAMIN CREMEL/AFP via Getty Images)

item.title: Japan Reiterates It Cannot Accept 25% Car Tariffs From US
item.description: Japan’s chief trade negotiator Ryosei Akazawa said the country can’t accept the US’s 25% tariffs on cars, adding that the Asian nation’s automakers produce far more cars in the US than they export to America.
item.dc:creator: Yoshiaki Nohara

item.title: US Accuses Three Mexican Financial Firms of Aiding Fentanyl Trafficking
item.description: The US government identified three Mexican financial firms for potentially laundering proceeds from illicit drug trafficking, effectively choking them off from the US financial system as it seeks to clamp down on cartels.
item.dc:creator: Michael O'Boyle

media:content.media:description: The US Treasury building in Washington, DC.

item.title: US Allows Ethane Cargoes to Sail to China But Not Discharge
item.description: The Trump administration has eased recent export limits on a critical petroleum product that’s used to make plastics — a shift that represents a modest pullback on curbs used as leverage in trade negotiations with China.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer A Dlouhy, Jenny Leonard, Nicholas Lua

media:content.media:description: Railroad tanker cars sit parked on the grounds of the Sunoco Logistics Marcus Hook Industrial Complex ethane terminal in Marcus Hook, Pennsylvania, U.S., on Friday, April 8, 2016. U.S. production of ethane, a key feedstock for petrochemical manufacturing, is expected to increase to 1.4 million barrels per day by 2017 as more facilities come online, according to Commodity Online. Photographer: Luke Sharrett/

item.title: Malaysian Agency to Forfeit $41.8M Linked to Ex-PM Probe: NST
item.description: The Malaysian Anti-Corruption Commission plans to seek forfeiture of 177 million ringgit ($41.8 million) in assets and cash it seized in its probe into former prime minister Ismail Sabri Yaakob, the New Straits Times reported.
item.dc:creator: Anisah Shukry

media:content.media:description: Ismail Sabri Yaakob Photographer: Samsul Said/Bloomberg

item.title: Brazil’s Congress Blocks Tax Decree in Fiscal Blow to Lula
item.description: Brazil’s Congress voted to block President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva’s proposed tax increases on some financial transactions, dealing a major blow to the government’s efforts to shore up its budget.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Carvalho, Martha Viotti Beck

media:content.media:description: Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva

item.title: Abrego Garcia Remains in Jail Amid Dispute Over Release
item.description: Kilmar Abrego Garcia, the Maryland man who the Trump administration mistakenly deported to a prison in El Salvador, remains in legal limbo after defeating a bid by the government to keep him locked up on criminal charges.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Hurtado

media:content.media:description: Katheryn Millwee holds a portrait of Kilmar Abrego Garcia outside the federal courthouse, Wednesday, June 25, 2025, in Nashville, Tenn. (AP Photo/George Walker IV)

item.title: Trump Says Three or Four People on List to Replace Fed’s Powell
item.description: President Donald Trump said he has three or four people in mind to succeed Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell when his term expires next year.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Lai, Jennifer A Dlouhy

media:content.media:description: The Marriner S. Eccles Federal Reserve building in Washington, DC.

item.title: Pentagon Posts Document With Fiscal Year 2026 Weapons Requests
item.description: The Defense Department’s proposed $961 billion budget for the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1 includes funding to purchase 24 F-35 fighters, 21 new model F-15 jets and two Virginia-class submarines, according to budget documents posted on the website of the department’s comptroller Wednesday evening.
item.dc:creator: Anthony Capaccio

media:content.media:description: The Pentagon in Washington, DC. Photographer: Daniel Slim/Getty Images

item.title: China’s Maritime Structures Near Japan and Korea Raise Tensions
item.description: China has stepped up construction of drilling rigs and other platforms off its east coast to tap into maritime resources such as natural gas and fish, raising the ire of Japan and South Korea and fanning fresh concerns about Beijing’s regional ambitions.
item.dc:creator: Alastair Gale, Sakura Murakami

media:content.media:description: Photo by Jam Sta Rosa/AFP via Getty Images Photographer: JAM STA ROSA/AFP

item.title: Treasury Close to Deal That Would Make ‘Revenge Tax’ Irrelevant
item.description: The Treasury Department is nearing a deal that would make the so-called “revenge tax” irrelevant, the agency’s second-in-command said, a development that could bring great relief to Wall Street investors worried about punitive tax measures on foreigners.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Flatley

item.title: US Extends Debt-Limit Special-Measures Period Through July 24
item.description: Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent told US lawmakers he’s extending the latest period for deploying special accounting measures to keep within the debt limit through July 24, 2025.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Flatley

media:content.media:description: Scott Bessent Photographer: Annabelle Gordon/Bloomberg

item.title: Top UK Business Leader Warns Rachel Reeves Not to Hike Corporate Taxes
item.description: Chancellor of the Exchequer Rachel Reeves should resist the temptation to raise levies on UK companies further because of the risk of strangling economic growth, one of the country’s biggest business lobbies said.
item.dc:creator: Freya Jones, Joe Mayes

item.title: New Zealand Māori Party MP Takutai Kemp Dies Aged 50
item.description: New Zealand member of parliament Takutai Moana Natasha Kemp, of the small opposition Māori Party, has died at the age of 50.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Brockett

media:content.media:description: WELLINGTON, NEW ZEALAND - OCTOBER 20: New Zealand flags fly in front of The Beehive during the Commission Opening of Parliament at Parliament on October 20, 2014 in Wellington, New Zealand. This is the first ceremony for the official opening of New Zealand's 51st Parliament. (Photo by Hagen Hopkins/Getty Images)
